DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said next week's meeting in China will be followed up by talks in Washington, while he also commented that a stable USD is important over a long period of time and will not advocate a weak USD policy in the near-term. (Newswires)

Politico journalist suggested US-China talks are to be held in Shanghai next week to allow the possibility of China President Xi joining the talks. (Politico)

China State Council said it is to lower real interest rates especially for small firms by using multiple tools. (Newswires)

BoJ officials are reportedly split on whether to loosen monetary policy next week or delay action, according to sources. Furthermore, many see no immediate requirement for ramping up policy support although others are concerned that delaying could trigger an unwelcome strengthening of the JPY, while cutting rates further is said to be one option for the BoJ and there has been a discussion on enhancing forward guidance but some have reservations over this. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson appointed Sajid Javid as Chancellor of the Exchequer, Priti Patel as Home Secretary, Dominic Raab as Foreign Secretary and Steven Barclay maintained his position as Brexit Minister. (Newswires)

  • EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Jul) 46.4 vs. Exp. 47.6 (Prev. 47.6). (Newswires) 
  • EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Jul) 53.3 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.6) 
  • EU Markit Comp Flash PMI (Jul) 51.5 vs. Exp. 52.1 (Prev. 52.2) 
  • German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Jul) 43.1 vs. Exp. 45.2 (Prev. 45.0)
  • German Markit Services Flash PMI (Jul) 55.4 vs. Exp. 55.3 (Prev. 55.8) 
  • German Markit Comp Flash PMI (Jul) 51.4 vs. Exp. 52.3 (Prev. 52.6)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e -10.835M vs. Exp. -4.011M (Prev. -3.116M). (Newswires)

Kuwait and Saudi officials have discussed resuming production from the Saudi/Kuwait neutral zone after settling technical issues. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran's President Rouhani reportedly hinted at possible swap of the UK vessel it seized last week for the Iranian tanker that was apprehended off the coast of Gibraltar earlier this month. (Al Jazeera) 

 

US

US President Trump will likely agree to a budget deal to keep markets happy in the short term and avoid election year austerity, according to sources. (Politico)

  • US New Home Sales Change (Jun) M/M 7.0% vs. Exp. 6.0% (Prev. -7.8%, Rev. -8.2%). (Newswires)
  • US Markit Manufacturing PMI Flash (Jul) 50 vs. Exp. 51.0 (Prev. 50.6)
  • US Markit Services PMI Flash (Jul) 52.2 vs. Exp. 51.7 (Prev. 51.5)
  • US Markit Comp Flash PMI (Jul) 51.6 (Prev. 51.5)

 

MARKET RECAP

Equities moved higher on Wednesday, with the SPX testing record highs, benefitting from a more supportive US-China trade backdrop and supportive rates, after Treasury Secretary Mnuchin confirmed he too will head to Shanghai for trade talks (where Chinese President Xi may also be present). In terms of earnings, Caterpillar (CAT) sunk on disappointing earnings; the co. beat on revenue expectations but saw orders decline more than the seasonal norm, and EPS was guided to the lower end of the FY outlook range. Boeing (BA) was under pressure after reporting earnings that contained the widely expected USD 5.6bln 737 MAX grounding charge, with desks citing concerns over possible 777 delays due to engine issues. Visa (V) struggled to stay in the green, despite posting a health beat on the bottom line, reporting strong growth in payments volume and backing guidance. United Parcel Services (UPS) shot higher after beating on the top and bottom lines and announcing plans to begin Sunday pickup and delivery as of next year. Snap Inc (SNAP) shot higher after the co. posted solid gains in daily average users across geographies and devices. Texas Instruments (TXN) moved higher despite guiding revenue lower, with some desks suggesting the adjustments had been not as bad as feared and noted the co. is shipping to Huawei again. Big tech firms, including Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet Inc (GOOG, GOOGL) and Facebook (FB), were under pressure after news broke that the co.’s would be targeted in a new DoJ antitrust probe. AT&T (T) and CBS Corp (CBS) were buoyed by comments from AT&T’s CEO during a conference call, where he noted negotiations with CBS are not “too far apart”. Chevron (CVX) advanced, despite premarket reports that the Trump Administration is split over whether to renew the energy co.’s Venezuela operations license. T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint (S) popped higher premarket on overnight news that the two co.’s had agree to sell USD 5 billion worth of wireless assets to Dish Networks (DISH), in a deal brokered by the DoJ that makes the two co.’s proposed merger more likely. Dish shares fell. Tesla (TSLA) shrugged off a negative WSJ article, which noted how its Model 3 sales have taken a hit in California as of late. LVMH (LVMH FP) reported Q2 earnings, with sales and profits both exceeding expectations, particularly in like-for-like sales of leather goods and fashion (+20% Y/Y). Upside was seen in LVMH’s US ADR (LVMUY) and in US competitors, including Tapestry (TPR), Ralph Lauren (RL) and Tiffany & Co. (TIF). S&P 500 0.5% at 3020, NASDAQ-100 0.7% at 8011, Dow Jones  -0.3% at 27270.

Disappointing European and US Manufacturing PMI data sent EGBs and Treasuries higher through the day. German Manufacturing PMI came in below expectations at 43.1, the lowest since July 2012, which helped set record lows in German yields, and naturally lower yields in Treasuries. The trend continued heading into the US equity open and was supported more by the US Manufacturing PMI print of 50, the lowest since September 2009. However, resistance emerged going into the 5-year auction, which tailed by 1bps and B/C ratio of 2.26x (six-auction average of 2.39x), indirects took the lowest share since December 2015 and dealers took their largest share since December 2018. At settlement the curve had flattened, with the 2s10s narrowing by 1.6bps, the 30-year yield had fallen by just under 4bps points and the 2-year yield by about 1.5bps. US T-note futures finished electronic trade higher by 6 ticks at 127.17+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 24th July 2019: SPX hits record high on trade optimism; PMIs disappoint
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, dollar flat, crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Mnuchin says China trade talks to come to Washington; Soft EZ & US PMI data; Johnson builds his cabinet; Saudi & Kuwait discuss resumption of crude production in neutral zone
  • COMING UP: Events; CBRT and ECB Rate Decision, Data; South Korean GDP, German Ifo Survey, US Durable Goods and Initial Claims, Canadian Average Weekly Earnings, Speakers; RBA Governor Lowe, ECB President Draghi, Earnings; Amazon, Alphabet, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Hershey, Southwest Airlines, 3M, Raytheon, Starbucks, Comcast, Intel Corp, Nokia, Kering, Saint Gobain, Atos, Scor, BASF, Volkswagen, Orange, Saipem, Vivendi, STMicroelectronics, Ab InBev, Roche, Sika, ABB.

 

* MARKET WRAP: Equities moved higher on Wednesday, with the SPX testing record highs, benefitting from a more supportive US-China trade backdrop and supportive rates, after Treasury Secretary Mnuchin confirmed he too will head to Shanghai for trade talks (where Chinese President Xi may also be present). Treasuries and other government bonds found support after multi-year lows were recorded in US and German Manufacturing PMIs in June, which also saw bidding in safe haven FX pairs with the data playing nicely into rationale for Fed and ECB rate cuts. In the backdrop, Boris Johnson stepped into position as the UK’s new PM and replaced the majority of the existing cabinet. The crude complex failed to hold onto gains from the 11mln barrel reported draw in US crude stocks; sellers emerged before the energy settlement after Saudi Arabia and Kuwait announced plans to restart oil production in their neutral zone.

* TRADE: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin comments that next week's meeting in China will be followed up by talks in Washington, combined with reports suggesting that the talks in China are being held in Shanghai to allow President XI to join the discussions, set a constructive tone. Elsewhere, Japan told the WTO that export controls to South Korea are based on National Security and are not an embargo. This was later followed by an announcement from the South Korean Deputy minister who stated his Japanese counterpart has rejected requests for a face to face meeting to discuss the trade row.  

* US MARKIT FLASH PMI (JULY): The US Markit Manufacturing PMI showed the lowest reading since September 2009, falling to 50 from 51.5 previously and missing expectations of 51. The report stated lower production volumes, which albeit only fell slightly, and was the largest decline since August 2009, paving the way for a negative reading along with a fall in employment and reduced stocks of purchases. The survey also noted that a downturn in the automotive sector and global economic uncertainty were factors behind the loss of momentum. BMO note that despite the positive readings from the Empire survey and Philly fed index, the chance of a manufacturing recession remains omnipresent. Services PMI printed an increase to 52.2 (prev. 51.5), the strongest rise in the service sector output in three months. However, Markit notes that the expansion was only modest and much softer than what was observed in Q1.  Markit state the growth of business activity was supported by July price discounting, as average charges were reduced the most since February 2016. Markit’s Comp figure came in slightly higher than previous at 51.6 (prev. 51.5), remaining above three-year lows in May, highlighting that private sector growth only signalled a “modest expansion”. Markit note inflationary pressures remained subdued and costs only rose slightly, with service providers reporting price discounting in July.

* EZ MARKIT FLASH PMIs (JULY): The EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI came in at 46.4, below expectations for 47.6 and last month’s 47.6. Meanwhile, EU Services PMI was 53.3, inline while the comp figure came in at 51.5 (a three-month low). “The manufacturing sector has become an increasing cause for concern… (with) the survey indicative of the goods-producing sector contracting at a quarterly rate of approximately 1%”, IHS Markit say. In reference to the inflation component, they add “inflationary pressures became increasingly subdued… (registering) the smallest increase since November 2016). The German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI came in at 43.1, below expectations for 45.2 and the previous reading of 45.0; “manufacturing output fell sharply in July, registering its steepest drop since March and one of the most marked contractions since 2009” said IHS Markit. The services number came in at 55.4, slightly above expectations for 55.3, but below the prior 55.8, while the composite number came in at 51.4. French Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI came in at 50.0, below expectations for 51.6 and last month’s 51.9 reading, services was 52.2, below expectations for 52.6, and comp. came in at 51.7. ING note that if the ECB is still undecided about whether to act tomorrow or in September, “this PMI has given the doves on the governing council even more ammunition.”

* ECB PREVIEW: 62 of 67 analysts surveyed by Reuters look for the Deposit Rate to be held at - 0.4%, with four looking for a 10bps cut, and one looking for a 20bps cut; Main Refi and Marginal Lending rates are unanimously expected to remain unchanged at 0% and 0.25% respectively. Note, markets currently price in 53.4% chance of a cut this week. With the ECB expected to stand pat on rates this week, participants will be eyeing any tweaks to the Bank’s forward guidance that would pave the way for a potential move in September, possibly as part of a broader easing package. Click here for the full report.

* IRAN: Iranian President Rouhani said that Iran was ready for “just, legal and honest negotiations”, alluding to the US, but caveating that not if negotiations mean surrender. Rouhani said that if the US continues to fly drones in Iran airspace, they will continue to be shot down. Talking about the vessel seizures, he suggested that if the UK were to release the Grace 1 tanker (currently held in Gibraltar), Iran could be interested in releasing the UK owned Stena Impero ship which it seized in the Strait of Hormuz last week; a separate Iranian official said the UK had sent a mediator to secure the release of the Stena Impero, but a UK government source denied the claims. Following the UK-EU efforts for launching a maritime security naval mission in the Strait of Hormuz, an Iranian military official said that any change to the Strait’s status opens the door to dangerous confrontation. Rouhani also said that the reduction of commitments under the 2015 Nuclear Deal can be reversed if the other signatories uphold their commitments (Europe purchasing Iranian crude), warning that a third step reduction in commitments will follow if remaining signatories do not reach a deal.

* BREXIT: Boris Johnson officially became UK PM and, as expected, a cabinet reshuffle took place; Sajid Javid took the role of Chancellor of the Exchequer, Dominic Raab took the role of Foreign Secretary after it was announced Jeremy Hunt would not be a part of the new cabinet, turning down a separate role. Steven Barclay remained as Brexit Minister, Pritti Patel took the role of Home Secretary, Michael Gove as Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, Ben Wallace as Defence Secretary and Liz Truss appointed as Trade secretary.

* US NEW HOME SALES: rose 7% to 646k, missing expectations of 660k whilst the prior was revised lower to 604k. Pantheon notes that the report is soft, but the monthly figures are very unreliable which often show margin errors as large as 15% either side. Thus, it is better to track the trend in comparison to the mortgage application numbers, which shows sales are running only slightly below the pace set by the mortgage application figures. Pantheon state this suggests new home sales ought to rise over the next few months.

* CBRT PREVIEW: All 18 analysts surveyed by Reuters expect the Turkish Central Bank to cut rates at the conclusion of its meeting on Thursday. Thus, markets will be focusing on how deep the move will be. The magnitude of the reduction could be between 100bps and 500bps, according to surveys, with the exact size likely to depend on how the Central Bank views the evolution of inflation. However, desks are cognizant of Turkey’s frail economy, and the Lira’s fragile nature amid geopolitical tensions with the US, as well as President Erdogan’s domestic battle with the Central Bank. It’s also worth keeping in mind that a 500bps is not unprecedented, given that the CBRT hiked rates by 625bps in September last year to stem Lira weakness. SocGen notes that the Lira overnight forward implied yield stands around 21.4%, with the 1-month rate at 19.6% which implies a rate cut greater than 180bps but below 440bps, although suggests it is hard to gauge what the Central Bank will do relating to fundamentals, since there are question marks over the credibility of the Central Bank following the abrupt CBRT leadership change. Click here for the full report.

* 7-YEAR PREVIEW: SocGen's analysts are slightly positive about the auction, and say the 7-year sector trades cheap in the curve versus 5s and 10s, and thinks it trades fair in asset swap versus older 5s in terms of relative value. The bank says that the sector could see good demand, noting that the 7-year WI yield currently trades near 1.91%, higher than the June auction stop out rate. SocGen also notes that the May 7-year auction saw good demand from investment funds and foreigners.

* TREASURIES: Disappointing European and US Manufacturing PMI data sent EGBs and Treasuries higher through the day. German Manufacturing PMI came in below expectations at 43.1, the lowest since July 2012, which helped set record lows in German yields, and naturally lower yields in Treasuries. The trend continued heading into the US equity open and was supported more by the US Manufacturing PMI print of 50, the lowest since September 2009. However, resistance emerged going into the 5-year auction, which tailed by 1bps and B/C ratio of 2.26x (six-auction average of 2.39x), indirects took the lowest share since December 2015 and dealers took their largest share since December 2018. At settlement the curve had flattened, with the 2s10s narrowing by 1.6bps, the 30-year yield had fallen by just under 4bps points and the 2-year yield by about 1.5bps. 

* WTI (U9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.89 LOWER AT USD 55.88/BBL; BRENT FUTURES (U9) SETTLE USD 0.65 LOWER AT USD 63.18/BBL: The energy complex failed to hold gains from bullish US inventory reports, with losses being extended heading into settlement as Saudi Arabia and Kuwait discussed resuming production in their neutral zone, prior estimates suggested the zone could yield an additional 500k BPD for each country. The DoE’s printed a much larger than expected draw at -10.8mln bbls, similar to the API figure on Tuesday; gasoline stocks had a small draw (-0.2mln) whilst distillates had a small build (+0.6mln); the Cushing, Oklahoma hub drew by -0.5mln bbls. Production dipped lower to 11.3mln bbls from 12.0mln, the lowest in almost a year. Whilst refinery utilization printed a surprise decrease of -1.3%; however, with the recorded period for the week’s data starting at the tail-end of the Tropical Storm Barry, the report is bound to be influence to some distortion due to the supply disruptions throughout the Gulf of Mexico.

* S&P 500 0.5% at 3020, NASDAQ-100 0.7% at 8011, Dow Jones  -0.3% at 27270, SECTORS; S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary 0.5%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples -0.6%, S&P 500 Energy 0.4%, S&P 500 Financials 0.9%, S&P 500 Health Care 0%, S&P 500 Industrials 0.4%, S&P 500 Information Technology 0.9%, S&P 500 Materials 0%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services 0.9%, S&P 500 Utilities 0.1%.

* US EARNINGS: Caterpillar (CAT) sunk on disappointing earnings; the co. beat on revenue expectations but saw orders decline more than the seasonal norm, and EPS was guided to the lower end of the FY outlook range. Boeing (BA) was under pressure after reporting earnings that contained the widely expected USD 5.6bln 737 MAX grounding charge, with desks citing concerns over possible 777 delays due to engine issues. Visa (V) struggled to stay in the green, despite posting a health beat on the bottom line, reporting strong growth in payments volume and backing guidance. United Parcel Services (UPS) shot higher after beating on the top and bottom lines and announcing plans to begin Sunday pickup and delivery as of next year. Snap Inc (SNAP) shot higher after the co. posted solid gains in daily average users across geographies and devices. Texas Instruments (TXN) moved higher despite guiding revenue lower, with some desks suggesting the adjustments had been not as bad as feared and noted the co. is shipping to Huawei again. Northrop Grumman (NOC) popped higher premarket after beating on the top and bottom line and guiding its FY adj. EPS view higher. Anthem Inc. (ANTM) fell despite beating on the top and bottom lines, with analysts focusing on notably higher Medical Loss Ratio (MLR). Notable other stocks benefiting from strong earnings; AT&T Inc. (T), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Chubb Limited (CB), Discover Financial Services (DFS), Edwards Lifesciences (EW), Freeport-McMoRan Inc. (FCX), Grainger (W.W.) Inc. (GWW), Robert Half International (RHI), Owens Corning (OC). Notable other stocks suffering after soft earnings; Amphenol Corp (APH), FLIR Systems (FLIR), Nasdaq, Inc. (NDAQ), Norfolk Southern Corp. (NSC), Rollins Inc. (ROL), Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO), Check Point Software Technologies Ltd (CHKP).

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Big tech firms, including Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet Inc (GOOG, GOOGL) and Facebook (FB), were under pressure after news broke that the co.’s would be targeted in a new DoJ antitrust probe. AT&T (T) and CBS Corp (CBS) were buoyed by comments from AT&T’s CEO during a conference call, where he noted negotiations with CBS are not “too far apart”. Chevron (CVX) advanced, despite premarket reports that the Trump Administration is split over whether to renew the energy co.’s Venezuela operations license. T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint (S) popped higher premarket on overnight news that the two co.’s had agree to sell USD 5 billion worth of wireless assets to Dish Networks (DISH), in a deal brokered by the DoJ that makes the two co.’s proposed merger more likely. Dish shares fell. Tesla (TSLA) shrugged off a negative WSJ article, which noted how its Model 3 sales have taken a hit in California as of late. LVMH (LVMH FP) reported Q2 earnings, with sales and profits both exceeding expectations, particularly in like-for-like sales of leather goods and fashion (+20% Y/Y). Upside was seen in LVMH’s US ADR (LVMUY) and in US competitors, including Tapestry (TPR), Ralph Lauren (RL) and Tiffany & Co. (TIF).

* FX WRAP: Further declines in EZ and US Manufacturing PMIs kept EURUSD within a 1.1128-1.1158 range; the data points seemingly strengthening the argument for looser monetary policy on both sides of the pond. The two currencies faired worse against safe havens; EURJPY, having only recently broken the June 120.81 low, continues to make headway towards 120.00, whilst USDJPY reversed three days’ worth of gains, whilst briefly slipping beneath the 108.00 handle, where a large option expiry kept the pair afloat. GBP was the G10 outperformer, rebounding across the board with Cable up to 1.2520+ at one point and EURGBP within single digits of 0.8900 before the Pound ran out of steam. Conversely, AUD sunk overnight following softer CBA PMI surveys and a more dovish outlook from Westpac (who now foresee another 50bps worth of easing via 2 OCR cuts at the start of Q3 this year and in mid-Q1 next year). IN EMFX; ZAR and TRY are both hovering close to 13.90 and 5.70 respectively, with the Rand boosted by more ‘one and done’ rate cut inferences from the SARB plus slightly firmer than forecast m/m inflation, while the Lira remains content in the knowledge that the US is, for the time being, still weighing sanctions and awaits tomorrow’s CBRT rate decision to see how much it cuts by.

* ZAR: Yesterday South African FinMin Mboweni presented a bill to parliament that would provide financial aid to state-owned utility co. Eskom, adding a further ZAR 59bln in support to the ZAR 69bln approved back in February. Note: Eskom is considered “too big to fail”, the company provides 95% of the country’s energy needs. Commerzbank note that, based on early evidence, tax revenues may well fall short of expectations, which when combined with another possible Eskom bailout, puts further pressure on public finances. As such, the bank thinks the risks of a rating downgrade have increased. ZAR has rallied from above 15.00 (vs. the buck) in early June to below 14.00 in late July, a beneficiary of the Fed and ECB’s recent dovish tilts, Commerzbank observes, “nevertheless, we recommend caution, as the rand remains vulnerable.”

analysis_details:
Further declines in EZ and US Manufacturing PMIs kept EURUSD within a 1.1128-1.1158 range; the data points seemingly strengthening the argument for looser monetary policy on both sides of the pond. The two currencies faired worse against safe havens; EURJPY, having only recently broken the June 120.81 low, continues to make headway towards 120.00, whilst USDJPY reversed three days’ worth of gains, whilst briefly slipping beneath the 108.00 handle, where a large option expiry kept the pair afloat. GBP was the G10 outperformer, rebounding across the board with Cable up to 1.2520+ at one point and EURGBP within single digits of 0.8900 before the Pound ran out of steam. Conversely, AUD sunk overnight following softer CBA PMI surveys and a more dovish outlook from Westpac (who now foresee another 50bps worth of easing via 2 OCR cuts at the start of Q3 this year and in mid-Q1 next year). IN EMFX; ZAR and TRY are both hovering close to 13.90 and 5.70 respectively, with the Rand boosted by more ‘one and done’ rate cut inferences from the SARB plus slightly firmer than forecast m/m inflation, while the Lira remains content in the knowledge that the US is, for the time being, still weighing sanctions and awaits tomorrow’s CBRT rate decision to see how much it cuts by.

* ZAR: Yesterday South African FinMin Mboweni presented a bill to parliament that would provide financial aid to state-owned utility co. Eskom, adding a further ZAR 59bln in support to the ZAR 69bln approved back in February. Note: Eskom is considered “too big to fail”, the company provides 95% of the country’s energy needs. Commerzbank note that, based on early evidence, tax revenues may well fall short of expectations, which when combined with another possible Eskom bailout, puts further pressure on public finances. As such, the bank thinks the risks of a rating downgrade have increased. ZAR has rallied from above 15.00 (vs. the buck) in early June to below 14.00 in late July, a beneficiary of the Fed and ECB’s recent dovish tilts, Commerzbank observes, “nevertheless, we recommend caution, as the rand remains vulnerable.”

subject: WTI (U9) futures settle USD 0.89 lower at USD 55.88/bbl; Brent futures (U9) settle USD 0.65 lower at USD 63.18/bbl
content: The energy complex failed to hold gains from bullish US inventory reports, with losses being extended heading into settlement as Saudi Arabia and Kuwait discussed resuming production in their neutral zone, prior estimates suggested the zone could yield an additional 500k BPD for each country. The DoE’s printed a much larger than expected draw at -10.8mln bbls, similar to the API figure on Tuesday; gasoline stocks had a small draw (-0.2mln) whilst distillates had a small build (+0.6mln); the Cushing, Oklahoma hub drew by -0.5mln bbls. Production dipped lower to 11.3mln bbls from 12.0mln, the lowest in almost a year. Whilst refinery utilization printed a surprise decrease of -1.3%; however, with the recorded period for the week’s data starting at the tail-end of the Tropical Storm Barry, the report is bound to be influence to some distortion due to the supply disruptions throughout the Gulf of Mexico.

subject: (Former) Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt will not be part of UK PM Johnson's government; reportedly he was offered a role but turned it down
US TO SELL USD 41BLN 5-YEAR NOTES ON 24TH JULY 2019 AT 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
* THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week sell a total of USD 131bln in 2-year (USD 40bln, Tue), 5-year (USD 41bln, Wed), 7-year (USD 32bln, Thu), as well as USD 18bln 2-year FRN re-opening on Wednesday. USD 72bln is set to mature at the month-end settlement, net supply is implied ta USD 59bln. TD Securities notes that the Fed portfolio run-off has slowed to USD 15bln per month (versus USD 30bln per month previously); and with USD 21.5bln of the SOMA portfolio maturing at month-end, the Fed will add on USD 2.3bln to 2s, USD 2.3bln to 5s, and USD 1.8bn to 7s.

* FIVE-YEAR PREVIEW: SocGen's analysts say the five-year sector lacks clear set up from a relative-value perspective, with current 5s trading cheap in asset swap vs older 5s, and it also trades rich on the curve vs 2s and 10s. That said, SocGen notes that the current 5 trades slightly special in repo, and SocGen says that combined with the relatively low dealer holdings, as well as the fact that the current when-issued yield for the sector is a tad above the last month’s auction stop, will benefit the auction. SocGen says it has a positive bias going into the auction.

Daily FX Wrap: Pound extends Boris bounce, as Aussie eyes RBA Governor Lowe
content:
GBP/AUD

Flanking the G10 ranks, as Sterling gets a 2nd post-Tory leadership vote wind and rebounds further across the board with Cable up to 1.2520+ at one stage and Eur/Gbp within single digits of 0.8900 before the Pound ran out of steam. All eyes now on Johnson’s inaugural speech as PM and the official unveiling of the new Cabinet after his Royal appointment, but for now the pro-Brexiteer appears to be getting the market’s benefit of doubt. Conversely, the Aussie has tumbled ahead of a speech from RBA Governor Lowe overnight amidst softer CBA PMI surveys and a more dovish outlook from Westpac that now foresees another 50 bp easing via 2 OCR cuts at the start of Q3 this year and in mid-Q1 next year. Aud/Usd has tested major chart support at the 100 DMA (0.6975-70), but holding in for now.

DXY

The broad Dollar rally has been dented if not derailed by preliminary Markit PMIs showing pronounced manufacturing sector weakness in line with other economies, and nudging the index back down towards 97.500. Note, the DXY had been probing through key chart resistance at 96.770, but faded ahead of 98.000 amidst the ongoing Gbp revival noted above and as other currency counterparts pared losses.

NOK/SEK/NZD/JPY

Also major outperformers, and especially the Scandi Crowns that have both rebounded sharply from recent lows vs the Euro on a mixture of technical retracement, EZ PMI weakness and pre-ECB positioning, while a stronger bounce in crude prices fuelled the reversal in Eur/Nok towards 9.6150 as well. Eur/Sek is hovering around 10.5100 and seeking some independent direction from Thursday’s Swedish economic tendency survey before the aforementioned ECB policy meeting. Elsewhere, the Kiwi has derived some traction from a larger than expected NZ trade surplus to consolidate/build gains back over 0.6700 vs its US peer and revisit 1.0400 against the Aussie, while the Yen has pivoted 108.00 and 4 bn+ option expiry interest at the strike with little reaction to BoJ sources suggesting division over whether to implement more stimulus next week or hold fire.

CAD/CHF/EUR

The Loonie also got a lift from oil to pull back further from 1.3160+ lows, but stalled around 1.3120, while the Franc straddled 0.9850 and 1.1000 vs the Euro that managed to stem EZ PMI declines vs the Buck ahead of the 2019 low and 1.1100 with the aid of the Greenback downturn and perhaps some inertia related to 1 bn option expiries at 1.1150.

EM

Usd/Zar and Usd/Try are both hovering closer to the base of 13.9520-13.8635 and 5.7355-5.7010 respective ranges, with the Rand boosted by more ‘one and done’ rate cut inferences from the SARB plus slightly firmer than forecast m/m inflation, while the Lira remains content or relieved that the US is still weighing up sanctions and awaiting tomorrow’s CBRT rate decision to see how low they go.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: bonds back on the front foot, but Dollar still drifting
content: No early NA data, but ahead of the Wall Street open and US Markit PMIs the return of stateside Treasury traders has coincided with a broader debt market revival. However, Eurozone paper is still holding a hefty post-PMI and pre-ECB premium as Bunds edge back towards their contract high and Italian BTPs hover just under a fresh 140.43 contract peak, while the 10 year GGB yield has now ducked under 2%. Conversely, reserved comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin about the Dollar and prospects of a Shanghai surprise without follow up trade talks have left the Greenback off best levels and the DXY back down through a key Fib after a brief/minor/false break above.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 24th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European stocks are marginally lower, FTSE 100 lags as miners slide
  • EUR pressured and Bunds spiked amid downbeat EZ flash PMIs, DXY extends gains above 97.500
  • US DoJ is reportedly opening broad antitrust review on large tech firms
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Flash PMIs, DoEs and US 5yr Note Auction
  • Earnings: Boeing, American Airlines, Allergan, Facebook, Ford, AT&T, Align Technology, Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Caterpillar, GlaxoSmithKline

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher with sentiment lifted by US-China trade hopes after reports US Trade Representative Lighthizer will lead a small team of negotiators to China next Monday for trade discussions. This underpinned major indices on Wall St. with outperformance seen in the trade sensitive sectors such as materials and industrials, although futures pared some of the gains after-market on news the DoJ is to open a broad antitrust review on the large tech firms. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were higher with broad strength seen in Australia aside from the mining sector, while gains in Tokyo were capped amid a downturn among JPY-crosses. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) showed a strong performance on the trade optimism which was also helped by US Commerce Secretary Ross who said he will deal with Huawei waiver applications within the next few weeks, while China was also said to be looking to make more agricultural purchases as a goodwill gesture. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with demand sapped following similar uninspiring trade in USTs amid the positive risk tone and with the BoJ also absent from the market today.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 100bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8860 (Prev. 6.8818)

China released a white paper in which it accused US of undermining global strategic stability and provoking competition among major nations, while there were separate reports that China International Capital Corporation said around 5mln factory jobs were lost in China amid trade tensions with US. (Newswires)

US 

US DoJ is reportedly opening broad antitrust review on large tech firms. (WSJ)

UK/EU

PM-elect Johnson will begin assembling a majority Brexiteer Cabinet today as he clears out Remainers to end “self-doubt” and get Britain ready for leaving the EU on October 31st. (Telegraph)

 

UK Foreign Minister Hunt’s future in the cabinet is in doubt after he resisted a demotion from his current post and turned down the offer of becoming the Defence Secretary, according to Sky News. Current Defence Secretary Mordaunt or Treasury Chief Truss could replace Hunt if he leaves his position. (Sky News)

 

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Jul) 46.4 vs. Exp. 47.6 (Prev. 47.6) (Newswires) EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Jul) 53.3 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.6) EU Markit Comp Flash PMI (Jul) 51.5 vs. Exp. 52.1 (Prev. 52.2)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses are marginally lower [Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%] following on from a relatively flat open as overall downbeat flash PMIs from Europe weighted on the region. UK’s FTSE 100 (-1.0%) lags its peers amid unfavourable currency action coupled with underperformance in heavyweight mining names following a barrage of broker downgrades. As such, Rio Tinto (-4.0%), BHP (-3.4%) and Anglo American (-3.1%) all rest at the foot of the index. Sectors are mixed with defensive sectors supported due to the current cautious risk tone. In terms of individual movers, ASM (+7.3%), ITV (+6.1%) and Akzo Nobel (+4.1%) shares are all fuelled by earnings and trade at the top of the Stoxx 600. On the flip side, Deutsche Bank (-3.7%) shares plumbed the depths post-earning after the German lender reported a larger than expected net loss and cut its FY 19 revenue guidance. 

FX

USD - Buck bulls have gleaned even more encouragement from unfolding US-China trade developments given that face-to-face talks look set to resume early next week, and Beijing offers to buy more agricultural goods as a good will gesture in response. Moreover, the Dollar continues to proffer from the demise of others and increasingly constructive technical impulses with the DXY eclipsing a Fib retracement level and inching closer towards the psychological 98.000 mark.

AUD/NZD - The Aussie has given up 0.7000+ status and is now threatening to slide below 0.6975 in wake of slowdowns in all CBA PMI readings overnight and yet another dovish RBA policy call looking for 2 further cuts in the OCR (Westpac this time eyeing moves in October and February 2020). All this ahead of comments from RBA Lowe in the early hours on Thursday and in contrast to the Kiwi that is keeping in contact with 0.6700 after a wider than forecast NZ trade balance, albeit due to a bigger miss on the import side vs exports.

EUR/CHF/CAD - The single currency has also been undermined by PMI surveys, and in particular the manufacturing prints showing France on the 50 threshold and Germany sinking deeper into contraction. With Eurozone M3 also softer than expected, rate cut odds have now tipped in favour of 10 bp for tomorrow’s ECB meeting and Eur/Usd is losing sight of decent option expiry interest at 1.1150 (1 bn) as a result, but holding above the ytd base and 1.1100 where big barriers lie. Meanwhile, the Franc has retreated further vs the Buck within a 0.9850-75 band, but remains above 1.1000 against the Euro pending Thursday’s ECB policy pronouncements and the SNB’s response, but the Loonie has clawed back some lost ground vs its US counterpart to meander between 1.3129-47 compared to 1.3164 or so at one stage on Tuesday.

GBP/JPY - Relative outperformers and bucking the overall trend, as the Pound maintains its recovery momentum following confirmation that Boris Johnson will take over the reins from Theresa May as Tory Party head. Cable has extended its rebound from near 1.2400 to 1.2480+ awaiting the official unveiling of the new PM and his Cabinet line up, with Eur/Gbp down towards 0.8925 and early July mtd lows. Similarly, the Yen is still displaying resilience in the face of overall Usd strength and upbeat risk sentiment despite ongoing geopolitical tensions, with a reluctance to stray too far from 108.00 where massive expiries roll off (4.3 bn) and technical resistance capping the upside (108.31 Fib).

EM - The Rand remains in the spotlight amidst comments from SARB Governor Kganyago underlining post-rate cut guidance for limited additional monetary stimulus and CPI data that was slightly firmer than anticipated in m/m terms. Usd/Zar is hovering just below 13.9500 as the Central Bank head highlights the fact that neutral rates have risen due to risk premia of late and this makes it tougher for further easing.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have hit a bit of a brick wall it seems, and several charts are flagging resistance around the new 174.51 contract high, while Gilts have not been able to breach the nearest upside technical area protecting their Sep19 pinnacle (132.45) and 10 year US Treasuries remain capped around 127-20+ with the corresponding yield holding on approaches to 2%. Hence, even though the macro impetus remains bullish for core bonds, and especially Eurozone debt, some caution may be warranted and prudent in the run up to the ECB on the premise that Draghi and co could disappoint hyped up dovish market expectations. More immediately, US Markit PMIs loom before more housing data after weak releases yesterday, and the 2nd T-note auction follows a rather lacklustre 2 year sale as FOMC bets favour -25 bp rather than -1/2 point.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are taking a breather from last night’s geopolitical-induced gains in which the benchmarks reclaimed USD 57/bbl and USD 64/bbl to the upside on reports that UK approached EU nations to join a European-led mission for safe shipping via the Strait of Hormuz. Furthermore, reports of a US delegation heading to China on Monday exacerbated upside in the complex on sentiment. Meanwhile, the mammoth drawdown in API crude stocks (-10.96mln vs. Exp. -4.0mln) added further fuel to the upside for oil, although the immediate jolt was quickly faded due to bearish components of the release including a surprise build in gasoline inventories, it’s worth noting that this week’s inventory data also captures the late effects of Storm Barry. Elsewhere, spot gold in is crawling higher as the yellow metal consolidates following its recent decline from 6yr highs. Copper prices are marginally lower amid the cautious risk tone, albeit remain above USD 2.70/lb, while Dalian Iron ore extended losses amid slowing demand in the wake of output restrictions on steel producers in China’s top steel-making city Tangshan.

API Weekly Crude Inventories (23 July) -10.96mln vs. Exp. -4.0mln (Prev. -1.4mln). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS 

Russia denied that it has apologies to South Korea over the alleged incident during the joint air exercise with China, reported via IFAX. (Newswires)

Iranian President Rouhani says the reduction of commitments under the Nuclear Deal can be reversed if other parties uphold their commitments, a third step reduction in commitments will follow if remaining signatories do not reach a deal. (Newswires)

Germany says it is too early to discuss German participation in European naval mission to secure Strait of Hormuz. (Newswires)

Iranian President Rouhani stated that the nation is ready to negotiate but not if it means surrender. (Newswires)

China Defence Ministry said Taiwan independence separatist forces remain the gravest immediate threat to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, while it added that it makes no promise to renounce the use of force in the strait. (Newswires)

subject: Fixed Income: fundamentally firm, but technically challenged?
content: Bunds have hit a bit of a brick wall it seems, and several charts are flagging resistance around the new 174.51 contract high, while Gilts have not been able to breach the nearest upside technical area protecting their Sep19 pinnacle (132.45) and 10 year US Treasuries remain capped around 127-20+ with the corresponding yield holding on approaches to 2%. Hence, even though the macro impetus remains bullish for core bonds, and especially Eurozone debt, some caution may be warranted and prudent in the run up to the ECB on the premise that Draghi and co could disappoint hyped up dovish market expectations. More immediately, US Markit PMIs loom before more housing data after weak releases yesterday, and the 2nd T-note auction follows a rather lacklustre 2 year sale as FOMC bets favour -25 bp rather than -1/2 point.

subject: FX Morning Colour: more PMI pain and Greenback gain
content:
USD

Buck bulls have gleaned even more encouragement from unfolding US-China trade developments given that face-to-face talks look set to resume early next week, and Beijing offers to buy more agricultural goods as a good will gesture in response. Moreover, the Dollar continues to proffer from the demise of others and increasingly constructive technical impulses with the DXY eclipsing a Fib retracement level and inching closer towards the psychological 98.000 mark.

AUD/NZD 

The Aussie has given up 0.7000+ status and is now threatening to slide below 0.6975 in wake of slowdowns in all CBA PMI readings overnight and yet another dovish RBA policy call looking for 2 further cuts in the OCR (Westpac this time eyeing moves in October and February 2020). All this ahead of comments from RBA Lowe in the early hours on Thursday and in contrast to the Kiwi that is keeping in contact with 0.6700 after a wider than forecast NZ trade balance, albeit due to a bigger miss on the import side vs exports.

EUR/CHF/CAD

The single currency has also been undermined by PMI surveys, and in particular the manufacturing prints showing France on the 50 threshold and Germany sinking deeper into contraction. With Eurozone M3 also softer than expected, rate cut odds have now tipped in favour of 10 bp for tomorrow’s ECB meeting and Eur/Usd is losing sight of decent option expiry interest at 1.1150 (1 bn) as a result, but holding above the ytd base and 1.1100 where big barriers lie. Meanwhile, the Franc has retreated further vs the Buck within a 0.9850-75 band, but remains above 1.1000 against the Euro pending Thursday’s ECB policy pronouncements and the SNB’s response, but the Loonie has clawed back some lost ground vs its US counterpart to meander between 1.3129-47 compared to 1.3164 or so at one stage on Tuesday.

GBP/JPY 

Relative outperformers and bucking the overall trend, as the Pound maintains its recovery momentum following confirmation that Boris Johnson will take over the reins from Theresa May as Tory Party head. Cable has extended its rebound from near 1.2400 to 1.2480+ awaiting the official unveiling of the new PM and his Cabinet line up, with Eur/Gbp down towards 0.8925 and early July mtd lows. Similarly, the Yen is still displaying resilience in the face of overall Usd strength and upbeat risk sentiment despite ongoing geopolitical tensions, with a reluctance to stray too far from 108.00 where massive expiries roll off (4.3 bn) and technical resistance capping the upside (108.31 Fib).

EM

The Rand remains in the spotlight amidst comments from SARB Governor Kganyago underlining post-rate cut guidance for limited additional monetary stimulus and CPI data that was slightly firmer than anticipated in m/m terms. Usd/Zar is hovering just below 13.9500 as the Central Bank head highlights the fact that neutral rates have risen due to risk premia of late and this makes it tougher for further easing.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures chase EZ peers higher post-feeble manufacturing PMIs
content: Only a fleeting set-back for UK debt and STIR contracts on their return to Liffe as Eurozone counterparts catapult on the back of preliminary Eurozone PMIs revealing even more weakness in the manufacturing sector as French activity stalled and German contracted faster. Gilts have now effectively matched near term resistance at 132.29 vs the July 4 contract high (132.45) and the 3 month strip is flat to 1.5 ticks ahead vs -2 ticks at one stage, while Bunds have sharply extended their contract high to 174.51 amidst widespread gains. The pan EZ release may not spark much more reaction and M3 also seems unlikely to rock the boat, while the only domestic data due is mortgage applications, so any material commentary emanating from the EU meeting to discuss Brexit in wake of Boris Johnson’s victory may be more pertinent for Gilts, Short Sterling and the Pound today.

subject: Iranian President Rouhani states that the nation is ready to negotiate but not if it means surrender
Several huge FX option expiries for today's NY cut
Bunds: almost, but not quite as the focus turns to Eurozone PMIs pre-ECB
content: The 10 year German benchmark is back in consolidation mode after the most concerted effort to turn full circle from early July contract high fell agonisingly short on Tuesday. Indeed, yesterday’s Eurex peak was 173.97 vs 174.05 at best on Independence Day and the near miss may leave the core Eurozone bond idling ahead of a busy midweek session and the penultimate piece of the macro jigsaw before Thursday’s ECB policy pronouncements in the form of preliminary PMIs (with Ifo completing the picture tomorrow). Note, however, the pull-back in Bunds has been relatively shallow again with losses only extending to 17 ticks so far, at 173.78, and futures now edging back up towards the early 173.88 apex. From a technical perspective, 173.56 represents near term support and was Tuesday’s intraday low.

content:

24th July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher with sentiment lifted by US-China trade hopes after reports US Trade Representative Lighthizer will lead a small team of negotiators to China next Monday for trade discussions. This underpinned the major indices on Wall St. with outperformance seen in the trade sensitive sectors such as materials and industrials, although futures pared some of the gains after-market on news the DoJ is to open a broad antitrust review on the large tech firms. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were higher with broad strength seen in Australia aside from the mining sector, while gains in Tokyo were capped amid a downturn among JPY-crosses. Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) outperformed on the trade optimism which was also helped by US Commerce Secretary Ross who said he will deal with Huawei waiver applications within the next few weeks, while China was also said to be looking to make more agricultural purchases as a goodwill gesture. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with demand sapped following similar uninspiring trade in USTs amid the positive risk tone and with the BoJ also absent from the market today.

content:

  • Asian equities were supported by reports that USTR Lighthizer will lead a small team of negotiators to China next Monday for trade discussions
  • US Commerce Secretary Ross said he will deal with Huawei waiver applications within the next few weeks
  • PM-elect Johnson will begin assembling a majority Brexiteer Cabinet today as he aims to get Britain ready to leave the EU by October 31st
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ and US Flash PMIs, DoEs and US 5yr Note Auction
  • Earnings: Boeing, American Airlines, Allergan, Facebook, Ford, AT&T, Align Technology, Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Caterpillar, Celgene, Tesla, LVMH, Deutsche Bank, Akzo Nobel, Iberdrola, Daimler, Deutsche Boerse, Moncler, Peugeot, GlaxoSmithKline

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher with sentiment lifted by US-China trade hopes after reports US Trade Representative Lighthizer will lead a small team of negotiators to China next Monday for trade discussions. This underpinned major indices on Wall St. with outperformance seen in the trade sensitive sectors such as materials and industrials, although futures pared some of the gains after-market on news the DoJ is to open a broad antitrust review on the large tech firms. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were higher with broad strength seen in Australia aside from the mining sector, while gains in Tokyo were capped amid a downturn among JPY-crosses. Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) outperformed on the trade optimism which was also helped by US Commerce Secretary Ross who said he will deal with Huawei waiver applications within the next few weeks, while China was also said to be looking to make more agricultural purchases as a goodwill gesture. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with demand sapped following similar uninspiring trade in USTs amid the positive risk tone and with the BoJ also absent from the market today.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 100bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8860 (Prev. 6.8818)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said he will deal with Huawei waiver applications within the next few weeks. Elsewhere, NEC Director Kudlow said China is looking to make more agricultural purchases as a goodwill gesture, while US Agricultural Secretary Perdue said US will pay a minimum of USD 15 per acre in aid to farmers impacted by the trade war. (Newswires/WSJ)

China released a white paper in which it accused US of undermining global strategic stability and provoking competition among major nations, while there were separate reports that China International Capital Corporation said around 5mln factory jobs were lost in China amid trade tensions with US. (Newswires)

UK/EU

PM-elect Johnson will begin assembling a majority Brexiteer Cabinet today as he clears out Remainers to end “self-doubt” and get Britain ready for leaving the EU on October 31st. (Telegraph)

 

UK Foreign Minister Hunt’s future in the cabinet is in doubt after he resisted a demotion from his current post and turned down the offer of becoming the Defence Secretary, according to Sky News. Current Defence Secretary Mordaunt or Treasury Chief Truss could replace Hunt if he leaves his position. (Sky News)

 

PM-elect Johnson will meet three times with US President Trump in his first 100 days in office as the new PM looks to cement the UK’s relationship with the US. (Telegraph)

FX

 

DXY held firm after the recent debt ceiling and budget agreement with both US Senate Majority Leader McConnell and House Speaker Pelosi suggesting there are sufficient votes to pass the deal. As such, the greenback’s major counterparts were subdued with EUR/USD below 1.1150 as markets await the latest clues from the upcoming ECB policy meeting and with GBP/USD also lacklustre after hardline Brexiteer Boris Johnson claimed victory in the Tory leadership race. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was steady above 108.00 as it remained propped up by a firmer greenback although JPY-crosses suffered from base currency weakness, while antipodeans were lacklustre in which AUD/USD underperformed and broke down support at the 0.7000 level after softer Australian PMI data and with Westpac calling for 2 more rate cuts from the RBA in October and February.

 

Australian CBA Manufacturing PMI (Jul P) 51.4 (Prev. 52.0). (Newswires) Australian CBA Services PMI (Jul P) 51.9 (Prev. 52.6) Australian CBA Composite PMI (Jul P) 51.8 (Prev. 52.5)

 

New Zealand Trade Balance (Jun) M/M 365M vs. Exp. 100M (Prev. 264M) New Zealand Exports (Jun) 5.01B vs. Exp. 5.29B (Prev. 5.81B) New Zealand Imports (Jun) 4.65B vs. Exp. 5.20B (Prev. 5.54B) 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were relatively flat overnight as WTI took a breather from the prior day’s gains where the geopolitical risk premium was once again in play after the UK approached EU nations to join a naval mission to secure passage through the Strait of Hormuz and amid reports the US may have downed more than one Iranian drone. In addition, a larger than expected drawdown in headline API crude stockpiles briefly added further fuel to the upside for oil, although the immediate jolt was quickly faded due to bearish components of the release including a surprise build in gasoline inventories. Price action in gold was restricted by the firm greenback and lack of safe-haven demand, while copper traded sideways and failed to benefit from risk appetite as it eyed a test of support at USD 2.70/lb and amid a 3rd consecutive decline in Dalian iron ore futures which slipped over 4% by the break.

API Weekly Crude Inventories (23 July) -10.96mln vs. Exp. -4.0mln (Prev. -1.4mln). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US may have downed more than one Iranian drone, according to Centcom Commander General Kenneth McKenzie. (Newswires)

UK approached EU nations to join a European-led naval mission for safe shipping through the Strait of Hormuz with France, Denmark, Italy and the Netherlands showing strong support, according to senior EU Diplomats. Furthermore, reports added that Germany, Spain, Sweden and Norway have also expressed interest in playing a role and that the mission could be run by a joint British-French naval command but would not involve the EU, NATO or the US directly. (Newswires)

Iran Deputy Foreign Minister said Iran is to secure the Strait of Hormuz and that it will not allow disturbances in shipping in this sensitive area. In other news, Iran is considering cutting imports from Brazil after an Iranian vessel was banned from refuelling at a Brazilian port. (Newswires)

China Defence Ministry said Taiwan independence separatist forces remain the gravest immediate threat to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, while it added that it makes no promise to renounce the use of force in the strait. (Newswires)

US

The T-plex was choppy throughout the Asian and European session before heading lower amid news US trade negotiators will be heading to China on Monday. Treasuries came under pressure going into the US equity open as equity futures pressed higher, with analysts also highlighting the large amount of corporate issuance in the day’s pipeline contributing to the selling. However, bidding was supported shortly after with gratitude to a disappointing US June existing home sales print alongside a multi-year low reading in the Richmond Fed Manufacturing Index. Selling resumed going into the 2-year auction, which recorded its first tail (0.2bps) in 2019 on a B/C ratio of 2.5x (prev. 2.8x); primary dealers also took an increased share of 31.6%, more-or-less in line with its 5-auction average. The T-Note fell to fresh lows later as it was announced USTR Lighthizer would be heading to China on Monday for face-to-face meetings with Chinese officials. At settlement, spreads across the curve were little changed with the 10-year yield up by approximately 2.5bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 7+ ticks lower at 127-11+.

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said he is confident we have the votes to get the budget deal passed through and US House Speaker Pelosi later suggested they have the votes to pass the budget deal. (Newswires)

US DoJ is reportedly opening broad antitrust review on large tech firms. (WSJ)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks gain amid US-China trade hopes
content:
Asia equity markets trade higher across the board with sentiment lifted by US-China trade hopes after reports US Trade Representative Lighthizer will lead a small team of negotiators to China next Monday for trade discussions. This underpinned the major indices on Wall St with outperformance seen in the trade sensitive sectors such as materials and industrials, although futures pared some of the gains after-market on news the DoJ is to open a broad antitrust review on the large tech firms. ASX 200 (+0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) are higher with broad strength seen in Australia aside from gold miners, while gains in Tokyo are capped amid recent downturn among JPY-crosses. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.1%) outperform on the trade optimism which was also helped by US Commerce Secretary Ross who said he will deal with Huawei waiver applications within the next few weeks, while the Global Times Editor said China has started to buy US farm products and called on the US to honour its commitment by lifting sanctions on Huawei.

In FX markets, the DXY remains firmer after the recent debt ceiling and budget agreement with both US Senate Majority Leader McConnell and House Speaker Pelosi suggesting there are sufficient votes to pass the deal. As such, the greenback’s major counterparts are subdued with EUR/USD below 1.1150 as it awaits the latest clues from the ECB policy meeting on Thursday and with GBP/USD also lacklustre after hardline Brexiteer Boris Johnson claimed victory in the Tory leadership race to become the next Prime Minister. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is stable above 108.00 as it remains propped up by a firmer greenback although JPY-crosses suffer from base currency weakness, while antipodeans are lacklustre in which AUD/USD underperforms after a breakdown of support at the 0.7000 level after softer Australian PMI data and with Westpac calling for 2 more rate cuts from the RBA in October and February.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful with demand sapped following similar uninspiring trade in USTs amid the positive risk tone and with the BoJ also absent from the market today.

China Global Times Editor said China has started to buy US farm products and that the US should also honour their commitment and act timely to lift sanctions on Huawei, while the Editor suggested that without this step, he doesn’t think there will be a deal and China's purchase of US farm products will not be sustained. (Twitter)

Other News
